dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impressive room serving as an ARTIST’S WORKSHOP. It’s empty, but evidence of frantic creative activity abounds. We PAN across the wall, crossing a series of meticulously hand-crafted DOLLHOUSES, mostly works in progress. As we drift past these unfinished dioramas, our trajectory beco clearer... We are moving in on an extraordinary sculpture of a beautiful, rustic CRAFTSMAN HOME, at 1:8 scale. Its front wall has been removed, exposing its rooms in graphic tableaux. This huge miniature is painstakingly detailed. adorned with shrunken props/decorations (flashlights, pil bottles, shoes, etc.) and teensy furniture, all flawlessl rendered and distinguishable ONLY IN SIZE from their full scale models. We continue to pan/track across the miniature, edging CLO AND CLOSER as we drift along its tiny rooms. We finally arrive at a miniature replica of a TEENAGE BOY’S BEDROOM the second floor. We push towards this until the ROOM FILLS THE FRAME. The bright morning sun beams in through its window. It become apparent that a handsome, skinny BOY is sleeping in the b This is PETER GRAHAM (17). We continue pushing gently in, remaining in a wide of the room (whose status as a miniature has now been confused). door opens and STEVE GRAHAM (47) - tall, broad-shouldered formal - pops his head in. He wears a black suit.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: All right, Petey. Wake up time. Peter stirs awake. Steve drops a folded-up BLACK SUIT AND on the foot of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here’s your suit. MAX, the family’s golden retriever, shuffles happily in through the door.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did your sister sleep in her room last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide on the house, revealing that it is IDENTICAL to the miniature that we saw in the workshop. The surrounding landscape is blanketed with SNOW.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 2. Steve exits a back door to approach a very large TREEHOUS It is joined to a sturdy oak and hovers fifteen feet abov the ground. We are subtly BOOMING DOWN from this wide vie (as Steve begins to climb the tree) to arrive at a parked - one of two family cars - in the foreground. Sitting in the passenger seat is a bereaved woman (45). S wears all black, and is beautiful in a worn way. This is ANNIE GRAHAM, and she looks emotionally exhausted. She wears a delicate NECKLACE bearing an ORNATE SIGIL, wh she compulsively fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve pokes his head into the treehouse, where he finds: CHARLIE - a plump, androgynous fourteen year old girl - l asleep on the floor. She wears a parka and pajama bottoms Beside her is a DRAWING PAD and an open SHOEBOX.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh my God, Charlie. Are you crazy? Charlie wakes up, her nose pink and runny. When she notic Steve, she frantically reaches to SHUT the shoebox.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is how you get pneumonia!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (getting up) It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Your mom’s in the car already, we're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moderately attended FUNERAL. (A large group of MEN AND WOMEN observe from the back.) Before the altar, an OPEN CASKET rests beside a blown up photo of the deceased ELLEN LEIGH, Annie’s 75 year old mother. Annie, Steve, Charlie (now wearing an oversized black dre over her pajama bottoms) and Peter sit in the first row o chairs. They listen as a LARGE WOMAN (60s) speaks in remembrance of Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: LARGE WOMAN
dialogues.text: Ellen was a tough one. She didn't mince words, she abhorred the sentimental, and she was honest. And I know that's how she raised her children, Annie and Charles - (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 3.

dialogues.speaker: LARGE WOMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably) - may he rest in peace... To always be honest... Half-listening (half-wincing), Annie’s attention is drawn CHARLIE, who makes a quiet CLICKING noise with her tongue This is a tic. Suddenly, a bird FLAPS out from the rafters, startling th congregation. The bird settles on a ceiling perch. It is a WHIPPOORWILL looks down, fixing its gaze on Annie. Annie looks very disturbed. Off-screen, the Large Woman continues.

dialogues.speaker: MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: Annie is now on the PLATFORM.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: I just wanna say first...it’s very heartening to see so many strange new faces here today. I know my mom would be very touched (and probably a little suspicious) if she could see this turn-out, so... Annie looks down to now read from a heavily edited loose- page. This is her eulogy. (Not used to reading in public, rarely looks up from the paper.)

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My mother was an intensely secretive and private woman. She had private rituals, private friends, private anxieties... It honestly feels like a betrayal just to be standing here talking about her... Annie pauses. She looks at the paragraph. It’s very long, begins with the sentence “My mother was a chameleon." She decides to skip ahead to the next paragraph.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She was a very difficult woman to read. If you ever thought you knew what was going on with her - and God forbid you tried to confront that.../ (stops...pauses...skips ahead) ...But when her life was unpolluted, she could easily be the sweetest, warmest, most loving person in the world...  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 4. Charlie is DRAWING a weepy caricature of Annie at the platform. Steve watches this in the corner of his eye.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pauses, skips again to the next paragraph) .-.-She was also incredibly stubborn. Which maybe explains me. Scattered, knowing laughter.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You could always count on her to always have the answer.... She stops short, eyes on the paper. The sentence would continue “and if she ever WAS mistaken - well, that was Y opinion and you were WRONG.” Suddenly remorseful, Annie (off-book) asserts:

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I did love her. Charlie is still drawing. Steve closes the notepad. He po to Annie: “Listen to your mother." Charlie grudgingly obliges.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She was especially strong about food. When I was a girl and I had to eat my veggies...

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The mourners have been invited up to view the deceased an say goodbye. Organ music plays as Annie, Steve, Peter (wh doesn’t look) and Charlie shuffle by. Charlie peers into the open casket to see her grandmother CORPSE. It wears a NECKLACE with a delicate SIGIL ORNAMEN (identical to Annie’s). The seams in the corpse’s make-up eerily apparent and the lips are slightly twisted. Unnerved, Charlie looks away. She meets eyes with a smili MIDDLE-AGED BLONDE MAN standing in the queue behind her. STARING at her - an overly sentimental look in his eyes. Disturbed, Charlie averts her eyes. “Yeesh."”

dialogues.speaker: SECONDS LATER
dialogues.text: An older WOMAN arrives at the open casket. Her finger is dipped into a small bottle of OIL. She quickly and covert STREAKS the oil along the corpse’s lips. Seeing this, a following mourner squints with bewildermen  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is at the wheel, driving back home. Annie sits passenger, and Peter and Charlie sit in the back. They dr past a gathering of DEER.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (to Steve) How did you keep from screaming during Judy’s speech?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Ha. Well, if you could...! Peter EYES the back of Annie’s head. She seems to grate o his nerves. Meanwhile, Charlie is back to making clicking noises with her tongue. She does this while unwrapping a CHOCOLATE BAR.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (to Steve) How about that bird flying in?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah, that was weird.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: That was too weird. The timing? It felt like it was my mom. Steve nods, betraying a look of CONCERN. Annie self- consciously backtracks:

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not actually, obviously. Just - it struck me. Annie notices Charlie eating the chocolate bar.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! Are there nuts in that?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Better not be. Annie returns her attention to the road. Steve lovingly t her hand. She smiles at him. Charlie, irritated, looks very tense.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (quietly) I don’t like going back without grandma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully) Well, sweetie...do you understand why we have to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie just tenses up, eyes narrowing onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is unlit and seemingly vacant. Off-screen, we hear FEET SCURRYING and a DOOR CLOSING. Ma the golden retriever, BARKS in reaction to this. A moment later, the front door opens and the Graham famil enters. They stamp the snow off their boots and remove th coats. Max runs up, desperate to greet them. Steve bends down to happily receive him. Charlie moves toward the stairs, still wearing her boots.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey hey -- shoes off. Charlie pulls off her boots. She and Peter start separate up the stairs. Steve, looking down, notices dried FOOT-PR around the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling out) See? What’s with all these footprints? I’m tired of reminding everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie is at her work desk. It’s a mess of paints, props, pieces, etc. She wears magnifying eye-glasses as she carefully paints eyes onto a SMALL DOCTOR FIGURINE for a MINIATURE HOSPICE. A figurine of an old woman - presumabl Annie’s mother - lies in a miniature hospital bed. Steve enters, disrupting Annie’s focus.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Just working. Steve casually rests a glass of water and a PILL on the table. She downs it without question.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Still toiling on the hospice?  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 7.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Between that and the pre-school. There is a half-finished MINIATURE PRE-SCHOOL in the corn

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: How far are we now? Seven months?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Six and a half.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yow. Comin’ up. Her eyes widen with stress.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Any title ideas yet? Annie grabs her laptop and pulls up a PDF for a poster promoting an upcoming EXHIBITION of her artwork. It featu a photo of a magnificent living room miniature. Below thi are the words “TITLE HERE” in bold, followed by “The Work Annie Leigh.”

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is the photo they wanna use. Ooh, I love that one.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: The gallery owner keeps suggesting Your Life in Miniature for the title.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What do you think of that? Annie looks at him, incredulous. “Are you serious?”

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No good?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: It’s horrible!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (conceding) Yeah. A little trite.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: A lot trite! Are you kidding? She won't stop suggesting it! Steve looks to a stack of LARGE MOVING BOXES in the corne They're marked “Mom’s Things” in Annie’s handwriting.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 8.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You want me to put that stuff in the attic?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: ...-Yeah. Maybe not just yet. INT. PETER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 8 Peter sits up in bed, holding a guitar. He improvises a clunky tune as a muted TV plays cartoons. His eyes are on TV. The door cracks open and Steve pokes his head in.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Goodnight, kiddo.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: ‘Night, dad.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: ..-What you playing?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Just plucking random strings.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (nods, then) You feeling okay about everything?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Yeah. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Little sad? Peter shrugs again. He clearly wasn’t fond of Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know. (pause) Okay, buddy. Love you. Steve KISSES in Peter’s direction. Peter kisses back. Ste walks off, leaving the door open. A moment later, Annie walks up to the doorway, still wear her magnifying eye-glasses. She’s holding a prop in one h a fine paintbrush in the other.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: ‘Night sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Goodnight. I’m sorry about your mom.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 9.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (pause) Thank you. I’m sorry about your grandma.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: ..-Thank you. Annie smiles, hesitates, and walks off. There’s a very lo tension between these two. After Annie is gone, Peter climbs out of bed to shut the door. He LOCKS it. INT. CHARLIE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 9 Charlie’s room is that of a young artist. The walls are covered in drawings, and the desks and other surfaces are littered with different HANDMADE HUMAN MANIKINS and SMALL STATUES (all made of disparate parts - mostly found objec Annie sits on the edge of Charlie’s bed. Charlie is under covers. Annie has opened Charlie’s drawing pad to see a CARICATURE of Annie’s mother’s corpse in its casket.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: That’s grandma?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: You know you were her favorite?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (looking away) No I wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (pouncing) Oh yes you absolutely were! Even when you were a little baby, she wouldn't let me feed you because she needed to feed you. It drove me crazy.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She said I was supposed to be a boy. Annie knows this. She hesitates, wanting to say the right thing.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: How do you feel about that? Charlie shrugs.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 10.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know I was a tomboy growing up? I hated dresses and dolls and pink. Charlie’s heard this before. She has tensed up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (looking away, quietly) Who’s gonna take care of me?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (mock offended) Ummm, excuse me? You don’t think I’m gonna take care of you?!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: But when you die...

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: ..+.-Then dad will take care of you. Or Peter. Charlie’s head remains turned. Discouraged, Annie turns b the page of the drawing pad. She now sees the caricature her, crying at the pulpit.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who's this one? No answer. Annie takes it personally, but pretends not to She closes the book with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You never even cried as a baby - you know that? Not even when you were born. Charlie ignores this.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you feel like you wanted to cry today? Without looking at Annie, Charlie shrugs a tense “I don’t know.”

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think that might feel like a relief? Charlie remains miles away. Annie looks up to notice that a difficult-to-read WORD (l like “Satony”) has been CARVED into the wall behind Charl bed. Annie pauses, lets it go, and then bends down to KIS Charlie’s forehead.  10 11 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 11.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Goodnight, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie enters. Outside the window: peaceful snowfall. Annie hesitates before walking over to the box labeled “M Things." She reluctantly opens it... The box is filled with bottled oils and herbs. At the top the box is a PHOTO ALBUM titled “Memories.” Annie opens i sift through photos of her mother. She lays the album bac into the box, and then notices a stack of worn HARDBACKS. pulls one out. “NOTES ON SPIRITUALISM.” This calls back unwelcome memories. Annie dumps the book into the box, and PUSHES the box away. Annie walks to the door and flips off the light, leaving room in darkness (save for the moonlight). She’s about to leave, but something makes her FREEZE. Standing motionless in a dark corner (almost too dark to out) is ANNIE’S MOTHER, ELLEN - wearing the same outfit a the funeral. She’s staring at Annie. SMILING. Annie, nearly paralyzed with fear, reaches for the light switch. Without looking away, she turns the light back ON Her mother is gone. Annie remains motionless.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Mom? Annie's eyes are now drawn to... A dusty older MINIATURE in the corner. It's a replica of Annie's bedroom. A figurine of Annie (in her early thirti BREASTFEEDS a baby. Standing beside her is a figurine of OLDER WOMAN (Annie’s mother) holding her naked BREAST out her nightgown. She leans over, offering it to the baby. Competing with Annie. Troubled by this, Annie walks briskly to the miniature an TURNS it away. It’s now facing the wall as Annie returns the door, flicks off the light, and leaves. INT. ANNIE & STEVE’S BEDROOM - MINUTES LATER 11 Annie climbs into bed with Steve.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: I just scared myself in the workshop.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 12.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh no. With what? Annie pauses. Thinks about telling him. Steve looks interested/slightly worried. Annie thinks better of it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: . No? She smiles “nah.”

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Goodnight. Annie turns off the bedside lamp and gives Steve a blunt kiss.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (before she can pull away ) Mm, mm - no you don’t. He EXTENDS the kiss, making it last. Then:

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie’s “special needs” class. Scrawled on the blackboard are the words “Quiet means Silence!” and all the students are indeed silent as they a quiz. The TEACHER (40s) walks along the rows of desks, overlook the quiz-takers. He comes to CHARLIE, whose quiz is upsid down. In her lap, she is assembling a small manikin’s bod with disparate found objects (wood, metal, cardboard, etc

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Are you done? (looking up, startled) What?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--Almost.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: (warmly) So maybe we finish the toy after the quiz? What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ...Okay. The teacher gently turns the quiz right-side-up. Charlie extremely tense through this.  13 13. Suddenly a PIGEON flies into the window, slamming its hea The impact breaks its neck. The classroom erupts with excitement - “Oh my God!” “Did see that?!” - but not Charlie. She stares tensely at her desk, still disturbed by the teacher's interference. Charlie’s EYES scan up. They alight on a pair of SCISSORS the Teacher’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter’s English class. The chalkboard reads: Themes - Escaping Fate. - Relationship between knowledge and responsibility. - "No man considered fortunate until he is dead." The teacher, MR. DAVIES (30s), tries to facilitate a grou discussion. He holds a copy of Sophocles’ The Women of Trachis.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES
dialogues.text: So if we're going by the rule that a hero is undone by his fatal flaw, what was Heracles’ flaw?

dialogues.speaker: SMART-ASS STUDENT
dialogues.text: Fucking his mom. Some laughter from the class.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES
dialogues.text: Wrong play, Sam. And watch your language. Meanwhile, Peter is being hypnotized by BRIDGET (17), the attractive girl sitting in front of him. Peter’s rapt attention is glued to the butt of her jeans.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, guys: What was Heracles’ flaw? Bridget now speaks up:

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Arrogance. This piques Peter’s interest.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES
dialogues.text: Okay - why?  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 14.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Because he literally refuses to look at all the signs that are being literally handed to him the entire play. Peter’s in love.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES
dialogues.text: Okay, interesting! So he thinks he has control.

dialogues.speaker: SMART-ASS STUDENT
dialogues.text: Plus he fucked his mom. More laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES
dialogues.text: (to the smart-ass) That’s two strikes, Sam. (back to the class) But also, don’t forget: Sophocles writes it so the oracle is unconditional. Meaning Heracles never had any choice. Right? Peter’s smartphone VIBRATES with a text.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, does this make it more tragic or less tragic than if he did have a choice?

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Less! Peter checks his text. It’s from Brendan. It reads: “Wann smoke a bowl at break?” This came from the BOY behind him

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES
dialogues.text: Okay: Why?

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: (already giving up) Because! Mr. Davies turns to Peter, who’s now composing a text in lap.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES
dialogues.text: Care to weigh in, Peter? Peter looks up, a deer in headlights.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: About which part?  14 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 15.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES
dialogues.text: Is it more tragic if it’s inevitable than if the characters had agency? Peter is not following.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: .-.-Because he had sex with his mom? Dead air. Mr. Davies gives Peter an unencouraging look. Another student picks up the slack:

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: I think it's more tragic - because if it’s all just inevitable, that means the characters have no hope and that they never had hope, because they’re just like pawns in this horrible, hopeless machine. Peter has now noticed BRIDGET looking at him. She gives h sardonic “nice try” smile. Peter smiles back, embarrassed She turns away. Peter’s smile turns to a longing stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recess. The DEAD PIGEON lies pathetically in the bushes below Charlie’s classroom window. Charlie stands nearby, staring at the pigeon. After some time, she fishes a pair of SCISSORS from her parka pocket (These are the scissors from her teacher's desk.) Charlie extends the scissors, fits the blades around the pigeon’s neck, and SNIPS OFF ITS HEAD. Charlie quickly POCKETS the pigeon head, and looks up to notice: An OLDER WOMAN (60s) sitting on a bench, just beyond the schoolyard fence. She is gazing at Charlie, sentimental. Charlie gawks at the woman, unnerved. Without breaking ey contact, she pulls a chocolate bar from her pocket. In the b.g., PETER walks past, joined by Brendan. Seeing chocolate, Peter casually asserts:  15 16 17 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 16.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No nuts, Charlie. This makes Charlie freeze up with tension. INT. PSYCHIATRIST’S OFFICE - AFTERNOON 15 Steve’s office is large and sparsely decorated. Steve sits in a leather chair with a notepad resting on h lap. Sitting opposite him is an extremely agitated, depre female PATIENT (40s). Steve studies her non-judgmentally.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: And how’s the anger?

dialogues.speaker: PATIENT
dialogues.text: Same. I just don’t care as much.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (optimistic) So not as consuming?

dialogues.speaker: PATIENT
dialogues.text: (gritted teeth) It's just as consuming, I just don’t care as much. Steve, stifling frustration, affects superhuman patience.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: And how’s your appetite been? With the Serafem...versus the Lexapro. INT. ANNIE’S WORKSHOP - DAY 16 Annie's laptop is open to a website: “Discernment of Pres Apparitions.” Annie, sitting at the Graham house model, is carefully painting a MINIATURE LAPTOP, featuring the very same webs INT. ANNIE’S MOTHER’S BEDROOM - DAY 17 We are looking through the open door into the HALL. Downstairs, the front door is heard opening.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello!

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi! Annie steps out into the hall and walks past the doorway. moment later, we hear her footsteps FREEZE. She soon retu into view, now looking very unsettled. She stares past us into the room...  18 19 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 17. ANNIE’S POV: The room is mostly EMPTY, save for the bed (stripped of sheets), a bookshelf, and various FRAMED PHO featuring members of the family. One photo: a portrait of Annie and her mother, standing side by side. There is als LARGE TRIANGLE (pointed northwest) that has been CARVED violently into the floorboards. Annie doesn’t react to the triangle. It was clearly alrea there. Annie leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve sits on the couch, having just turned on the news. still wearing his coat. Annie enters.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Were you in my mom’s room?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What? No.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: The door was open. Steve makes a “hmm” face. The front door is heard opening, and Annie goes to the FO where Peter and Charlie are entering.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey guys. How was school?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Did either of you go into Grandma's room recently? They both squint. “Why would we go in there?”

dialogues.speaker: PETER

dialogues.text: (entering) Annie, what is that smell-- But he FREEZES when he sees the state of the demolished r Annie sits in her chair, completely surrounded by smashed splintered wood.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (stunned) ...What happened? He looks at Annie and almost immediately understands. She this. His heart breaks.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t wanna look at it anymore. Steve stares at her for a very long time. He then grabs t PHONE and storms into the hallway, dialing a number.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (rising) Hey! Who are you calling?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the upstairs hallway window, A CAR pulls up to pa behind Steve’s car. A pleasant, well scrubbed man (50s) emerges to walk toward the house. This is DR. STETSON. There is a KNOCK at the door. It is heard OPENING.

dialogues.speaker: DR. STETSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi Steve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming, Bob. Yeah: forgive the smell. I think something died in the walls. Annie is standing in the upstairs hallway, listening.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (sighs) She’s upstairs right now.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 89. Annie takes this as her cue. She walks defiantly down the stairs. She arrives at the bottom, in the FOYER. Dr. Stet acknowledges her with a big smile.

dialogues.speaker: DR. STETSON
dialogues.text: (warmly ) Hi Annie.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Dr. Stetson.

dialogues.speaker: DR. STETSON
dialogues.text: Can we all sit somewhere and talk?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (disdainful) Yeah, let’s make ourselves at home. Annie sits in a chair in the corner. Dr. Stetson takes a chair and brings it nearer. Stetson sits across from Anni without crowding her. (A couple flies will be buzzing aro throughout.)

dialogues.speaker: DR. STETSON
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Not amazing.

dialogues.speaker: DR. STETSON
dialogues.text: Can you talk about why?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (blunt) Uh - because my daughter was killed and now my psychiatrist husband is calling over his peers to investigate me. Steve glowers.

dialogues.speaker: DR. STETSON
dialogues.text: Nobody's investigating you, Annie. Annie just stares at him. DR. STETSON (CONT’D) Can I ask how you are?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I’m lucid. I’m in mourning and I’m trying to cope, and he’s supposed to be my partner, so forgive me if I’m not bouncing off the walls to see you.  90.

dialogues.speaker: DR. STETSON
dialogues.text: Nobody's trying to do anything against you right now, Annie. I promise you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Then stop patronizing me please. Stetson takes a long pause. He levels with her:

dialogues.speaker: DR. STETSON
dialogues.text: What’s all this about ghosts? And seances?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (direct) I thought I felt a presence. I was hopeful, as you can imagine. It was fleeting, and now I’m back to grieving.

dialogues.speaker: DR. STETSON
dialogues.text: Okay... All right. (moving on) And why did you destroy your work?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (turning back to Stetson) Because it’s my work. Annie's eyes are stone. Brief pause.

dialogues.speaker: DR. STETSON
dialogues.text: (relenting) Fair enough. So I’m gonna ask you some annoying questions now, Annie. (making sure to not patronize) I can see that you're lucid. This is just simply what I have to do. Okay? (first question) What day is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: DR. STETSON
dialogues.text: When in the month? 115 Through the foyer window, we see Steve and Dr. Stetson OUTSIDE. This is from Annie’s POV. Dr. Stetson seems to be explaining something to Steve. St nods, frustrated.  116 91. We see Dr. Stetson say “I’m sorry, I can’t” and then he w off to his car. Steve sulks back toward the house. Steve enters. He looks at Annie.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: What were you hoping? That I'd tell your psychiatrist friend that we brought back our dead daughter? You think I don’t know how that sounds? Steve nods, numb. He walks past her, toward the stairs. A pauses before following him up. INT. ANNIE’S WORKSHOP - MOMENTS LATER 116 Steve has entered the workshop. He walks heavily around t ruins. Annie steps in. Watches him.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You worked so hard for this show.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ - Fuck the show. You're ignoring this!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m not ignoring anything - believe me. Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (tensely, measuredly) I won’t indulge this behavior anymore.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I won’t. I can’t allow it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ignore everything! If you can’t find it in one of your books!

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Indulge”?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: “Allow” now! Jesus! Listen to how you’re just clinging! (pointing) You’re the one who’s gonna go crazy, Steve. If you keep just denying what’s in front of you. Steve stares at her, overwhelmed. He looks down to notice his feet: the figurine of Annie’s Mother, holding out her breast. Steve lets out a defeated sigh.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (tears building) You know, Annie... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 92.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can still build a shrine to the terrible stuff. Doesn’t mean you have to destroy anything good.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Well, it’s not anything good. It’s nothing. It means nothing. This -— (kicks a piece of wood) - is what I cared about.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Except for that one. Steve is pointing out the pristine Graham House replica. looks it over. Something makes him chuckle bitterly to himself.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice touch. Annie looks at Steve, not understanding. She walks over t the miniature. She sees that something has been ADDED to Peter’s bedroom HEADLESS FIGURINE (now wearing Peter’s clothes) is lying Peter's bed. The color drains from Annie’s face.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was wondering when Peter would get switched with Charlie. Annie is covering her mouth with her hands. She is having horrible revelation. Her eyes then SCAN UP to notice something else... The figurine of ANNIE (on her knees, face in her hands) i now in the ATTIC replica. The figurine is dressed in a NIGHTGOWN (the same one that Annie is wearing now), excep its front is covered in blood. Defeated, Steve leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (bitterly) I didn’t sleep at all last night. If you can believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rattled and extremely tense, Steve sits at the couch, whi is dressed with a blanket and pillow. He uncaps a PRESCRIPTION BOTTLE (sleeping pills).  118 119 120 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 93.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (mumbling) Always you - right Steve? You hold it all together. He draws out TWO PILLS and knocks them back. He then hesitates before pulling out one more. He DOWNS it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the open door of the workshop (whose lights are n off), Peter is seen TURNING OFF THE LIGHTS in his bedroom looks out into the hall, paranoid, and then shuts the doo Several FLIES adorn the hallway walls. This was seen from ANNIE’S POV. She’s sitting in the dark among the wreckage of her work. She’s still in shock over inexplicable additions to the Graham replica. Suddenly she HEARS the faint sound of a PENCIL VIGOROUSLY SCRATCHING PAPER. It’s coming from down the hall. She hesitates before rising and entering the HALLWAY... More and more flies have collected. They seem especially prominent around the ATTIC DOOR on the ceiling. Noting this, Annie continues to follow the sound of drawi to arrive at... INT. CHARLIE’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 119 The door is open. The lights are OFF. The sound of PENCIL FEVERISHLY SCRATCHING PAPER is heard, although the room i completely empty. Annie stands at the door. She hesitates before turning on light. CHARLIE’S DRAWING PAD rests on Charlie’s bed. It’s open t mostly blank page, but a DRAWING IS MATERIALIZING on it. is then FLIPPED (as if by wind) to the next page, where a drawing begins. We can’t yet see the content of the drawi Annie approaches the drawing pad to investigate. Her eyes already buzzing with fear, now widen with HORROR. INT. PETER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 120 The door is closed and the lights are off. Peter is inbed trying to sleep. Silence, save for a buzzing fly. Then... A CLICKING of the tongue. Peter’s eyes OPEN. He slowly lo up, scanning past the bed, to SEE... CHARLIE is standing in the dark corner of the room (where Peter mistook his hoodie for a person). Charlie stares at Peter with unblinking eyes. It’s almost too dark to make out. Another CLICK.  121 122 123 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 94.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Charlie? A long silence. Charlie slowly opens her MOUTH, but then head DROOPS forward and rolls OFF her shoulders. It tumbl to the floor and rolls toward Peter, but when it rolls in block of moonlight (cast from the window), it’s revealed be a Nerf basketball. Peter glares at the ball. A quiet GROWLING is heard from door. Peter looks up. The door is now OPEN and Max stands in the doorway. He se to be disturbed by Peter - or rather, by something standi behind Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (terrified) What is it, Max? Suddenly TWO HANDS materialize from behind Peter’s head. grab his face, grasping under his chin. They TUG BACK on head, as if trying to yank it off. Peter SCREAMS. Max runs in to attack, but the DOOR SLAMS IN HIS FACE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max paws aggressively at the door, barking wildly. Suddenly, Max's HIND LEGS are lifted, as if by invisible hands, and TUGGED back by a great, vacuuming force. He is SUCKED across the hall and down the stairs. We FOLLOW the mortified dog as it’s pulled all the way down to the FOYE The FRONT DOOR IS OPEN and Max is deposited violently out the house. The door SLAMS SHUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is FAST ASLEEP on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Peter! Peter! INT. PETER’S BEDROOM - SAME TIME 123 Peter has just been released by the phantom hands. He’s frantic. ANNIE is now standing in the room.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong, baby?! What happened?!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What are you doing?!  124 95.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You were pulling on my head!

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: What?! Peter looks terrified of her.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No I wasn’t! I just came in! You were screaming! Peter is crying.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I saw Charlie in the corner and then you started pulling on my head.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Peter! I would never do that to you! Are you crazy? I would never hurt you. How could you even think that? Peter just stares at her through frightened tears.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -..-You saw Charlie in what corner? Peter can’t answer. He’s horrified.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Peter. I don’t know what’s happening or what you just saw, but I’m stopping this. Do NOT tell dad what you just said to me. Please. It's NOT true. Something’s going on, and I’m the only one who can stop this. Do you understand? I’m the only one who can fix it. Peter stares unblinkingly at her. INT. CHARLIE’S BEDROOM - SAME TIME 124 Charlie’s DRAWING PAD is open. We track slowly in, reveal the CONTENT of two of the drawings... Both are crude, violently drawn sketches of PETER’S FACE, the EYES are replaced with X’s. The faces are framed by furiously sketched TRIANGLES.  125 126 127 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 96. A BREEZE blows in from the window, flipping to the NEXT P more of the same - and then the next page - still more of same - and then the next page, etc... Annie’s HAND enters to seize the drawing pad. She leaves room. Max's barking persists in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie has started a FIRE in the fireplace. (In theb.g., Steve is still asleep on the couch.) Annie clutches Charlie’s drawing pad, gazing into the fir She inhales deeply, holds her breath, and then THROWS the in. At first it resists the flames, but then, the EDGE of sheet begins to BURN. Annie watches this, eyes glued to the fire. But the shoul of her SHIRT has sprouted the tiny beginning of a FLAME. is the same size as the burgeoning flame at the drawing p edge. Annie doesn’t even notice. The flame spreads slowly along the drawing pad’s edge. As this happens, the flame on Annie’s shoulder SPREADS ALONG ARM. Annie notices this and panics. She desperately tries stamp out the fire, but it’s no use. The fireplace-fire starts to CONSUME the edges of the dra pad. Simultaneously, ANNIE’S ARM IS ENGULFED FOR A MOMENT FLAMES. The fire on her arm is mimicking the fire that’s eating the book. Annie SCREAMS, pulls the drawing pad out of the fire, and STAMPS OUT the flames. As she stamps it out, the fire on arm is duly EXTINGUISHED. Annie understands now. She’s tied to the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MOON hangs large over the house. We then SLAM CUT to MORNING. The moon has been replaced by a shrill SUN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter steps out of his bedroom, backpack slung over his shoulder. He clearly didn’t sleep last night and his eyes buzzing with anxiety. He looks down the hall at the workshop’s DOOR, which is open by the faintest CRACK. He hesitates and walks off. Behind the workshop door: ANNIE stares through the crack, making sure that Peter leaves.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 97. 128 INT. JOAN’S APARTMENT BUILDING - THIRD FLOOR - MOMENT Annie, looking frighteningly determined, emerges from the elevator of JOAN’S BUILDING. She’s still wearing her nightgown under a coat. She rushes to JOAN’S DOOR and kno No answer. Annie knocks again, more urgently. 129 INT. JOAN’S APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS 129 Nobody's home. We are pulling back from the DOOR (as Anni knocking persists) to REVEAL the apartment... It looks mostly the same, but it’s now adorned in cloths drapes that feature various SYMBOLS. One of these is an ORNATE SIGIL (which we recognize as the one on Annie’s necklace). This is the Sigil of PAIMON, and it can now be found all over the room. The TABLE at which Annie and Joan performed the seance (w was then covered in a table-cloth) is now bare, revealing that the tabletop has a LARGE TRIANGLE carved into it (pointing to the northwest). Resting in the middle of the triangle is a PHOTO OF PETER. Beside this is an ATHAME (ritual dagger), a scattering of herbs, and finally... A primitive DIORAMA (the same that we saw earlier on Charlie’s desk, but now finished). Standing center stage crude manikin of a human torso whose head is an actual SEVERED RAVEN HEAD. Atop the head is an aluminum-foil CRO Three other sculptures BOW ON THEIR KNEES to the raven-he figure. Their heads are the severed PIGEON HEAD (now decomposing), a severed RAT HEAD and a severed SQUIRREL H Annie's knocking continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie ceases knocking. She looks DOWN to notice that she’ standing on... The WELCOME MAT. “JOANIE.” Annie's mind starts racing. She thinks for a moment and t it hits her! Annie RACES back to the elevator. A SCHOOL BELL RINGS, bridging our CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUNCH TIME. It’s overcast, dark and windy. Students mill about in flapping clothes. Just beyond the high school fence is a ROAD with heavy traffic. PETER is seated at an empty table near the fence eating (or rather, not eating) the cafeteria food.  132 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 98. The TRAFFIC NOISE is loud and imposing. Peter LISTENS to losing himself in the white noise. But there’s something looming underneath the traffic noise... It's like a distant YELLING, but too distant to make out. Slowly it becomes clearer, more distinct. It’s a WOMAN’S VOICE and it’s yelling “Peter.” Peter looks up. Where is it coming from?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (still vague) ...I expel you...! Peter looks around. Soon his eyes settle on something... Across the road, on a far sidewalk, JOAN is standing. She looks raving mad. She’s staring directly at Peter and she screaming like a lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: SATONY, DEGONY, EPARIGON
dialogues.text: Terrified, Peter rises from his seat. He looks around to if anyone else is noticing this. Nobody is.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Peter looks back at her. They MEET EYES.

dialogues.speaker: GET OUT, PETER
dialogues.text: Peter breaks the gaze. He looks around, appealing to any/ of the circulating kids. It’s clear that none of them see hear this. How is that possible?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: INT. ANNIE’S WORKSHOP - DAY 132 Annie runs in from the hallway. She rushes to the BOXES marked “Mom’s Things.” She opens first box and finds a HAND-EMBROIDERED WELCOME MAT. It’s exact same style as Joan’s. Embroidered into it is the na “ANNIE”. Under that is another mat, bearing the name “CHARLES” and featuring the now-familiar sigil of PAIMON. Annie goes to the next box. She dig through a collection herbs and oils, and beneath those, she finds a familiar hardback: NOTES ON SPIRITUALISM. Below this, a couple oth hardbacks: one that appears to be a GRIMOIRE (book of spe and the other titled INVOCATIONS.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 99. INVOCATIONS’ cover features an esoteric sigil. Annie open the book to find that it’s filled with vivid etchings of DEMONIC POSSESSION RITUALS. Annie goes to a MARKED PAGE. It features an illustration beastly man with a hulking body and a strangely effeminat face. He rides a dromedary and wears a crown. Tied to his is a collection of SEVERED HEADS. Behind him is a queue o frolicking ghouls, all headless and all playing instrumen A title reads “King Paimon (God of Mischief)." Annie finds a HIGHLIGHTED PARAGRAPH: "When successfully invoked, Paimon will possess the most vulnerable host. On when the ritual is complete will Paimon be locked into hi ordained host. Once locked in, a new ritual is required t unlock the possession." A sentence underlined in pencil reads: "Paimon is Male, t covetous of a male human body." The next page features an etching of a man sitting atopa mountain of treasure. A caption reads: “The riches to the conjurer." Annie comes to the TITLE PAGE of the book. There isa handwritten NOTE. It reads: My darling, dear, beautiful Annie, Forgive me all the things I could not tell you, as TI truly could not. Please don’t hate me and try not to despair your losses. You will see in the end that they were worth it. Our sacrifice will pale next to the rewards. Love, Mommy Mortified, Annie throws the book into the box, and digs deeper to find TWO PHOTO ALBUMS, familiarly titled “Memories.” Annie flips through one of the albums. For a while, nothi of note. But then she FINDS something... A PHOTO of ANNIE’S MOTHER, 20 years younger, standing wit JOAN, also 20 years younger. They both wear replicas of Annie's NECKLACE - the one bearing the now-familiar sigil Paimon. Stunned, Annie continues through the photo album. She fin SEVERAL MORE PHOTOS FEATURING JOAN, who's often standing the background. Always wearing the necklace. She and Anni Mother were evidently close friends. Another photo: Annie’s mother guides a baby bottle into B CHARLIE’s mouth. The bottle’s milk is polluted with black herbs.  133 134 135 100. Finally, Annie comes to a particularly bizarre photo. It features Joan pouring gold/silver coins over Annie’s Moth head. Annie’s Mother, wearing a tiara, is weeping/laughin tears of joy. They are surrounded by an intimate, APPLAUD audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Students are returning to class. Peter walks trembling down the hall. Any lingering kids disperse to enter their classrooms. Peter approaches his classroom, a gnawing apprehension taking him over. Suddenly, from behind Peter, a FLASH of light STREAKS acr the length of the hall. It sweeps past Peter. He FREEZES. The light seems to disappear at Peter’s CLASSROOM. Peter stares at the door. Through the door’s window, MR. DAVIES (the teacher) turns see Peter. They lock eyes. Davies smiles expectantly. Feeling pressured, Peter walks to the classroom. He ENTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hallway is crawling with flies. Annie, still holding the photo album, enters (from the Workshop) to investigate. The ceiling’s ATTIC HATCH is now covered in more flies th ever. It’s clearly the source of the infestation. Annie, eyes crazed with paranoia, stares at the hatch. A short (but accessible) rope hangs from it, asking to be pulled. Annie pulls on the rope, slowly OPENING the attic hatch a releasing its retractable stairway. A HORDE OF FLIES esca the attic. Annie hesitates before climbing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attic is dank and claustrophobic. There is one window letting in scant moonlight. Otherwise, the space is obscu in utter darkness. Annie pokes her head in. At the foot of the entrance is a FLASHLIGHT. Annie takes it, turns it on, and shines its b into the shadows. Flies are everywhere. Their buzzing permeates the room.  136 101. Waving away the flies, Annie explores the space. It’s fil with discarded pieces of the family’s past. Old cribs, a mattress, toys, etc. Finally, Annie’s FLASHLIGHT dawns on something. A FIGURE lying prostrate in the corner. Annie approaches it. The f get louder. Annie finally gets close enough to SEE... It is a WOMAN’S CORPSE, and upon closer inspection, its H is seen to be MISSING. From the white and wrinkled hands, it’s evident that this was an old woman. She is also wear a WHITE SILK ROBE - identical to the one that Charlie saw corpse wearing earlier in the woods. (Is this Ellen Leigh corpse?) A large TRIANGLE has been drawn in chalk around body. Annie GASPS, staggers back, and bends over to RETCH. As s does so, the flashlight’s beam crosses something on the VAULTED CEILING above the body. Annie pauses before raisi the flashlight. She trains it on the ceiling to reveal... THE SIGIL OF PAIMON has been painted onto the ceiling in dry BLOOD. Flies crawl across its coarse black-red stroke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sits at the back of the class. He WRINGS his hands, anxiety mounting. He’s still thinking about the woman (Jo who was yelling at him. Mr. Davies stands at the chalkboard. Written on the board “Punishment brings wisdom.”

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES
dialogues.text: So, everyone feels justified: Iphigenia’s murder was commanded by the gods - so really Agamemnon had no choice. And Clytemnestra is driven by revenge, just like Orestes when he returns... Suddenly, Peter hears something behind him. A distant CLICKING of the tongue. We focus in on Peter’s EAR. Separ by a few seconds each, the clicks become clearer and more present with every CLICK. It’s as if the source is nearin Soon it’s loud enough to be RIGHT NEXT TO PETER’S FACE. Suddenly, as seen from behind, PETER’S ARM SPIKES UP INTO AIR. Because we’re behind him, we don’t see Peter’s face. tense arm is HELD there, as if being pulled by an unseen force. The clicking sound continues. Mr. Davies turns to notice Peter.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling on him) Peter.  102. Mr. Davies waits, but after a moment, his expression dark into concern.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Peter, are you okay? We now reveal PETER. His face is CONTORTED with terrible stress, as if his head were gripped by an electric vice. eyes are locked open; his eyeballs darting around, as if appealing for help. His hand remains stiffly raised and h seems to have difficulty breathing. In fact, his face is about to turn purple. PETER CLICKS HIS TONGUE. He’s now the one clicking.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVIES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Peter. What’s wrong? Bridget, staring at Peter, looks especially disturbed. Pe CLICKS again.

dialogues.speaker: I...
dialogues.text: Suddenly Peter GASPS a horrible, gurgling gasp. It sounds like an agonized SQUEAL, much like the one we heard from Charlie during her allergic attack (before her decapitati

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: (terrified) Can he breathe?! A spit-bubble forms on Peter’s lips as he struggles hopelessly to speak. But then-- Peter’s head is SLAMMED FACE-DOWN into his desk. It holds there, trembling with tension. His face is SMEARED across desktop, as if a great pressure is being applied to the b of his head. One can almost hear Peter’s nose CRUNCHING. Peter’s head suddenly swings back up, as if being YANKED the hair. He is held upright for a moment, revealing that eyes are pitch-red with tears. His nose is also bleeding lightly. He looks extremely disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Peter’s head is SLAMMED back down, into the table. Blood BURSTS out of his now-broken nose. The class screams! Peter, suddenly in possession of his faculties, KICKS him back. He stumbles out of his chair, knocking over the des he staggers backward. He has been RELEASED from whatever just gripping him.  137 138 139 140 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 103. He SCREAMS, throwing his arms around, fending off whateve was. He breaks down in SOBS, fraught with terror. The class is completely silent. INT. STEVE’S OFFICE - DAY 137 A haggard Steve sits in his office, nursing a scotch. His cell phone VIBRATES. It’s ANNIE. Steve just stares at it. Letting it vibrate. It stops. After a moment, the office phone RINGS. He looks at it. Thinks about answering. Doesn't. He turns in his chair, raising the scotch to his lips. Ignoring the phone. He downs the glass. We now reveal the office phone’s CALLER ID. This call is coming from Peter’s High School.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The land-line rings. It’s the high school, now calling th Graham house. Nobody is home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie sits in her car, parked on the street. She is waiti in the driver seat, eyes crazed. She watches the house, holding her cell phone at the ready. A car drives by. She turns to investigate. It’s not Steve

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (to herself) Goddamn it, Steve. Come home. INT. STEVE’S OFFICE - SAME TIME 140 Steve is still in his office, eyes closed, leaning back i his chair. Clinging to the peace. The phone rings again. He sets his drink on the table and grudgingly answers.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hello? Pause. Steve suddenly becomes alert.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? What happened? (listens for a moment) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 141 142 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 104.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. Yes. I’m coming now. Which hospital?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is now driving home. PETER is asleep in the back se His nose is HEAVILY BANDAGED and his eyes are black and b Steve looks at the rear-view mirror while he drives. Watc his son sleep. Steve looks back to the road to see -- he’s about to runa red light. He STOMPS on the brake. Despite the harsh stop, Peter remains asleep. Steve grips the wheel, on the edge of his seat. A moment tense silence and then: the floodgates open. Steve starts CRYING, overwhelmed. After a moment of this, he regains composure. The light goes GREEN. INT. ANNIE’S CAR - LATE AFTERNOON 142 Annie is still waiting anxiously in her car. Steve’s car is seen pulling into the Graham driveway. Ann heaves a relieved sigh - “finally!” But then she notices Steve is pulling an unconscious Peter out of the back sea She sees Peter’s bandaged nose and PANICS. Annie jumps out of the car and bounds over. She’s grippin her mother’s photo album.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Oh my God what happened?! Steve turns to Annie as she arrives. He’s in no mood for histrionics. Annie GASPS at the sight of Peter’s face.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who did that?!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: He did apparently. Smashed his own face into his desk, hard enough to break it. This only feeds Annie’s paranoia. She covers her mouth wi her hands.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (needing to tell him) Steve...  143 105.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (blunt) Please: just take his feet. Annie hesitantly gathers Peter’s feet. Steve proceeds tow the house, carrying Peter by his underarms. INT. PETER’S BEDROOM - DAY 143 Outside, Max's BARKING is heard. It will persist through following scene. Steve and Annie lay the comatose Peter into bed. Steve lo down at Peter, sapped. He’s avoiding Annie’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Steve. Steve waits for her to continue.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...Upstairs, in the attic... When you were gone, I went up there. Steve closes his eyes, not wanting to hear whatever’s com

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s a decapitated body. An old woman... Steve’s eyes open, numb. He looks blankly at Annie.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reacting) That’s what all the flies are!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (zero inflection) A body?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go upstairs. Look for yourself. Whose body?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: I think it might be my mother’s. I think! I can’t tell! The skin is black and she’s all distended, but it’s an old woman and the head is gone... Go see for yourself. Steve STARES at her before walking into the hall and approaching the attic hatch.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then there’s more.  144 145 106.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: More than your mother’s headless body. Of course. Steve reaches for the attic hatch. He pulls it down and a mass of FLIES escapes. Steve pauses, now much more nervous about what he’s about find. He begins to climb the stairs. Annie now RUNS downstairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie rushes to the fireplace. She starts a FIRE. Max's barking continues off-screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hatch is still open. We hear from within the attic:

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jesus fuck! Annie has run back upstairs. Sounds of distress (from above) as Steve rushes to the st and stumbles down into the hallway. He’s pale with shock.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the fuck! There’s more.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Why haven't you called the police?!

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: The police can’t help us! This makes Steve pause. Did Annie do this?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Who is that, Annie? Annie squeezes her mother’s photo album.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Do you remember Joan, my friend? Her grandson died and she took me to her apartment? Steve’s eyes are harrowed.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to himself) It did look like your mother.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 107.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Listen! She taught me how to do the seance. I didn’t even want to know. But she brought her grandson back, and I saw it and I felt it - just like you did with Charlie. Steve eyes Annie with growing revulsion. She now opens th photo album. She’s frighteningly energetic.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This was my mother’s album. Okay? Now look: this woman, right here, that’s her! That’s Joan! Annie is pointing at a photo of Joan (20 years younger) standing with Annie’s mother (20 years younger). Annie sp quickly to prevent Steve from interrupting.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She never mentioned knowing my mother and I never met her before, but she approached me, she consoled me, and she told me about the seance, she showed me how, and now - look:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve can’t listen to this, but Annie desperately draws h attention to the photo of Annie’s Mother being showered i coins by Joan. Annie points at the NECKLACE.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s the necklace my mom gave me. Right? It’s my mother’s necklace. Right? Now Annie points out another photo: her mother posing wit Joan - both wearing the same necklace.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're both wearing it. And they're wearing it in every photo! Steve, now completely pale, doesn’t react. He’s staring a Annie like she’s a contagious disease.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And look at the pattern! Did you see up there? This was painted above the body. Right?! In blood?!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (dawning on him) ..-You dug up the grave.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: What?!  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 108.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was you, wasn’t it? When you were going out, “to the movies"? You're not even listening!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (horrified) And when the cemetery called... (outraged at the thought) I didn’t tell you because I didn’t want to worry you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Goddamn it! LISTEN to me, Steve! I know you don’t trust me - there’s nothing I can do_about that - but they put a curse on us, and when we brought back Charlie -

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We didn't bring back Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) - we made a PACT with something! I don’t know what it is, but it’s in the house and it wants Peter! Annie pulls out Charlie’s DRAWING PAD. She opens it and f through the sketches of Peter with his eyes X’d out.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I watched these pages fill. They’re all of Peter. She looks up at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Steve: I don’t know what I did, but Peter’s in danger and I’m the one who started this. Annie takes Steve’s arm. He recoils at his wife’s touch. leads him toward the STAIRS.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we destroy this book, it’1l take me too. I tried to burn it - I tried - but my arm caught fire. On its own. As if I was linked to it, because I am linked! I know that now. But if we don’t destroy this...Peter will... She's too overwhelmed to finish her thought. Steve’s eyes register no compassion. He skeptically follows her down t stairs toward the LIVING ROOM.  109.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It needs to be me, Steve. It’s my fault! I need you to throw it in the fire. Steve just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t do it! I can’t throw it in! I’m too scared. But if you don’t, it’ll be Peter. I know it will. (breaks down crying at the thought) It‘’ll be our son! Annie puts the drawing pad in Steve’s hand. She closes hi fingers around it. She tries to calm herself down.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please baby. I can’t do it. I need you to throw it in the fire. Annie takes a canister of LIGHTER FLUID and proceeds to D the drawing pad. She then looks at Steve with great love sadness.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even if you can’t believe me: You're the love of my life. Annie KISSES him passionately. It has the desperation of farewell kiss. Steve’s lips are stone.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love you, Steve. I love you so much. And I love Peter so much! Annie is crying hysterically. Max’s barking continues.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please! Throw it in! Steve walks in a horrified daze toward the FIREPLACE. But then -- he STOPS SHORT. He turns to Annie.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m not doing this anymore with you, Annie.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (panicked) What? No.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: This isn’t helping you. You're very sick and I need to call the police.  146 147 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 110. That does it. Annie storms toward Steve, SEIZES the drawi pad, runs to the fireplace, and HURLS the book into the f It is immediately CONSUMED by the flames, and then, like clockwork-- STEVE IGNITES INTO A RAGING BALL OF FLAMES. He cries out he is instantaneously swallowed up by the screaming fire. Annie can’t even scream. She’s frozen in horror. Her eyes LOCKED on the sight of her husband’s burning. And what's more, the ominous STREAK OF LIGHT has returned - now boun wildly around the room. Max’s off-screen BARKING has reac an insane pitch. We see Steve’s searing reflection in Annie’s fixed pupil. fire is impossibly violent. Now, at the scene’s shrieking apex, the streak of light settles on Annie - entering her

dialogues.speaker: SLAM TO BLACK
dialogues.text: Silence. A distant drumming fades in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WOODED AREA behind the Graham house. It’s snowing. A drum circle seems to be in progress somewhere unseen. Repetitive, minimal PERCUSSION (like subdued war drums) thumps faintly and steadily in the distance. INT. PETER’S BEDROOM - SAME TIME 147 Silence. Max’s barking has STOPPED. Peter’s eyes blink OPEN from his deep sleep. He bolts up a start. He’s in his room, under the covers. He squints with pain. He reaches to touch his nose, but discovers the heavy plaster bandage. Outside Peter’s window: the TREEHOUSE. A dim, golden ligh like candlelight - flickers from within. Peter stares at it. The drums are barely heard in the b.g They will continue. The drums are momentarily drowned out by the sound of a C DRIVING BY outside. Its HEADLIGHTS gently illuminate Pete room, scanning the walls (in pale blue) as the car drifts For the briefest moment, in this fleeting light, we see.. ANNIE, still wearing her nightgown, in the top corner of room. She seems to be FLOATING WEIGHTLESSLY. She’s so elevated, in fact, that her head is turned to the side an her cheek pressed against the ceiling.  148 111. There’s something still and composed about her; something resolutely NOT Annie. Her eyes are WIDE and her face expressionless. She’s behind Peter, STARING at his back. doesn’t notice. The car has now passed, and the room is obscured again in darkness. Annie is no longer clearly visible. Peter senses something behind him. He pauses, listens. Th he begins to TURN. Annie, back pressed against the wall, scrambles (in a sil panic) across the wall and OUT the door. She seems to be WALKING across the wall’s surface. Peter looks back just as Annie has left. He didn’t see he Peter climbs out of bed. He goes to leave the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Peter enters the hallway, a SHARP CLANGING SOUND is he downstairs. Peter freezes. A sustained REVERB fills the house. It sounded like it came from a piano. Peter remains motionless, listening.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Dad? Flies are everywhere. Peter walks over to his parents’ BEDROOM. He peers in. It’s empty. He turns back to the hall.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom? Dad? Peter looks up at the ATTIC HATCH, now closed. The SOUND FLIES is especially aggressive up there. He then notices that ANNIE’S MOM’S BEDROOM DOOR IS OPEN. looks inside. EMPTY. He closes the door. Peter continues warily down the hall. He approaches the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? Peter leans to peer down the stairs. He sees nothing. He slowly proceeds downward.  149 150 112.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter arrives at the bottom of the stairs. The foyer is empty. Peter notices the PIANO. It seems to have been tampered w The lid is open and a couple of the wires have been SNAPP Peter carefully walks through the foyer, eyes scanning around. Paranoia building. He approaches the LIVING ROOM, which is faintly illuminat by an off-screen flame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter stops at the doorway. His eyes travel across the wa to finally come to... The FIREPLACE. The last of a dim fire (mostly embers) crackles in the pit. And lying before the fireplace is... A CHARRED, BLACK CORPSE. It lies twisted on the rug. Peter stands frozen, trying to discern what it is. He tak reluctant step forward and slowly approaches the dark fig Peter finally comes close enough to SEE... The body’s HEAD has been violently AMPUTATED. The PINK/RE the exposed neck contrasts garishly with the crisped whol The body is on its back, arched and contorted. Peter looks at the HANDS. The fingers are curled into desperate claws. One finger bears STEVE’S WEDDING RING. Peter opens his mouth to scream, but all that comes out i muted gust of air. Tears well in his eyes. He can’t even summon the strength to look away. And above him... ANNIE is huddled up into a corner of the ceiling. Her fac twisted with grief and fear, and she is shaking her head “no, no, no, no, no” — as if pleading with the back of Peter’s head, like a frightened animal. She holds PIANO W pulling it taut with both hands. Wringing blood. Peter FREEZES, sensing something behind him. He slowly tu but not toward Annie... Peter looks to the other corner of the room. The CLOSET D is cracked open. Peter SQUINTS at it. Standing in the dar closet, barely visible, is a MAN IN A RED CLOAK - staring him. Peter is paralyzed. He then SENSES something in the corner of the ceiling - w Annie was. His eyes scan tensely to the corner, but Annie now GONE.  151 152 153 113. Pregnant silence. Suddenly, from behind Peter, Annie BURSTS SCREAMING out o the darkness, dashing towards him. Peter RUNS squealing out of the room. He sprints for the STAIRS. Peter bounds up the staircase, but at the top step, he tr over his own foot. He crashes to his knees, scrambling to back up. Behind him, we hear Annie pursuing. Peter races madly through the HALLWAY. The attic hatch is inexplicably OPEN. He dashes for the ATTIC STAIRS. He runs up the stairs and immediately RETRACTS them - jus Annie reaches him. Peter manages to pull the attic hatch SHUT, almost catching Annie’s bloody fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter LOCKS the floor’s hatch. There is a mad POUNDING fr beneath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie is UPSIDE DOWN and straddling the ceiling (as thoug gravity were no longer a thing). She pulls at the attic k SLAMMING her head into the hatch. She bangs her head crazily against the ceiling, over and over. With every strike, she POUNDS her forehead harder a more wildly against the hatch - like a mad bull, trying t break through by sheer force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter stands in the dark, screaming and crying as the pounding persists. It keeps growing harder, faster, more insane - until it STOPS. Peter listens... Nothing. Just the shrill cacophony of buzzing flies. Beside him, at his feet, is a dwindling BL CANDLE.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (terrified) Mommy ? Peter looks up. BLACK CANDLES HAVE BEEN SET UP ALL AROUND ATTIC. Their flames dimly illuminate the clutter. Peter now looks to the CORNER that earlier enshrined the headless corpse. The corpse is now gone, but something ti has replaced it. The distance and weak light preclude Pet from identifying it.  114. Peter begins to approach the corner, tears streaming. He the bloody sigil on the vaulted ceiling above. As he walk the buzzing gets LOUDER, more concentrated. Peter continues warily toward the corner, his fear rising The buzzing has gotten even louder. Finally Peter gets cl enough to SEE... In the center of the chalk-etched triangle is a PHOTOGRAP PETER WITH HIS EYES X’d OUT. Stunned and confused, Peter REELS back, knocking over a candle. The corner goes dark. Peter is weeping uncontroll now. He starts backing away, toward the room’s center. Hi eyes remain glued to his photograph. PETER (CONT’D) (to himself, crying) Please. This isn’t happening. You need to wake up. Peter’s teeth are chattering. He’s hyperventilating. His trembling silhouette is framed by the WINDOW behind him. Outside the window: dreamy snowfall. Peter continues backing up, but something makes him FREEZ prolonged GROAN, accompanied by the sound of WIRE being wrapped and tightened around FLESH. It’s coming from a so about twenty feet away, BEHIND him. This is followed by a swifter, HARSHER SOUND - like a saw being dragged through flesh. A pregnant PAUSE and then the sound REPEATS. A bri pause and it REPEATS again. Peter slowly turns around. His eyes travel up to SEE... ANNIE has somehow gotten in. She floats weightlessly in t air. (She is faintly illuminated by a candle below her.) has looped the PIANO WIRE around her own NECK, which is already straining blood. She TUGS on one end of the wire. SAWS through her neck. She TUGS on the other end of the w It saws even deeper.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mommy ! Annie keeps sawing, FASTER and HARDER and with more ruthl persistence. The sawing sound is horrible. Peter, screami TURNS away, only to see: A MIDDLE-AGED BLONDE MAN, dressed in a red cloak, near Pe He’s SMILING giddily. (We will recognize him as the man w was smiling at Charlie at Annie’s mother’s funeral.) Behi him, two SMILING OLDER WOMEN. They are crouched together, illuminated by a nearby candle-flame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter has landed face-first into the SNOW. Small shards o glass are embedded all over his body, but nothing too serious. Peter lies motionless for a long time. We cut WIDE to a BIRD’S EYE VIEW looking down on Peter. H lies face-down in the blue-white snow, inanimate. The win blows softly. We HOLD on this peaceful, static wide. After a moment, a SHADOW floats gracefully across the snow. It belongs to Annie, who must be above us - but the shadow seems headle The shadow drifts out of frame, followed by the vague, familiar STREAK OF LIGHT. The light, however, STOPS at Pe It dances on his back... steadies... disappears into him. After a moment, Peter’s head RISES languidly from the sno His face is marked by a few minor GASHES (from the glass) looks up, EYES STRANGELY CALM. They even look a bit cloud He looks ahead to the TREEHOUSE... PETER’S POV: Annie’s floating body has arrived at the treehouse, which is still glowing by candlelight. She asc into it. For a split-second, before she disappears into t treehouse, we see that ANNIE HAS NO HEAD. Peter rises to his feet, hollow-eyed. His gaze trained on treehouse. He seems to be in some sort of TRANCE - much l the trance that Charlie entered earlier. After a moment o standing, staring at the treehouse...Peter CLICKS HIS TON With that, he begins walking slowly toward the treehouse. He passes MAX'S DEAD CARCASS, sprawled across a snow-buri garden. As Peter nears the treehouse, he looks up to its OPEN WINDOW... Through the window, from Peter’s low-angle POV: a birdcag hangs from the treehouse ceiling. It houses a manic WHIPPOORWILL. We cut to a WIDE of the treehouse as Peter arrives at the tree’s base. Peter pauses. Looks up. After a beat, he begins to leaden climb up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, having scaled the tree, pokes his head through the floor-hatch and climbs in.  116. The walls are lined with black candles, and before Peter several MEN AND WOMAN (some elderly, some middle-aged) BO on their knees, foreheads against the floor. They are all dressed in RED CLOAKS. Standing behind Peter (on the opposite side of the treeho is the terrible object of their reverence. He turns to se A GIANT, 6’ WOOD-FIGURE MANIKIN. Placed atop its shoulder (in lieu of a head) is CHARLIE’S DECAPITATED HEAD - now i advanced state of decomposition. The nose is still smashe in, much of the face is black with rot, and it wears asil CROWN. One hand grips a wooden SCEPTER. The manikin’s oth hand is raised to extend its first two fingers and thumb; third and fourth fingers are bent (like a Christ figure). Bowing at the foot of the manikin is ANNIE’S HEADLESS TOR blood pooling at the neck. Beside her corpse, also prostrated, is ANNIE’S MOTHER’S HEADLESS CORPSE (still dressed in white silk, but in a worse state of decay). Peter's eyes are WIDE, but still blank. They are FIXED on Charlie’s head. He looks more confused than horrified. Peter turns around to face the groveling red-cloaked worshippers. They now seem to be bowing in his direction. Among the worshippers is JOAN - her forehead pressed to t floor. Peter, unnerved, looks away. He notices... A photo portrait of ANNIE’S MOTHER on the wall. She sits upright and her expression is severe. The frame bears an engraving: “Queen Leigh” We come to a CLOSE-UP of Peter. He looks confused and sca (although not in a way that feels like Peter). We will HO on this CU for the remainder of the scene. The sound of someone RISING. This person (Joan) shuffles Peter to lift the crown off of Charlie’s head. She then c to stand (now off-screen) before Peter. After a moment, t CROWN enters frame to be placed ceremoniously onto Peter' head. Peter has TENSED up, desperately avoiding eye contact wit Joan. He SENSES something behind him. He looks back (and pan-tilt) to see... The headless corpses of Peter’s family are now inexplicab bowing in his direction. Peter turns forward again - overwhelmed. He looks trapped Trembling. His milky eyes are welling with tears.  117.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (quietly, trying to soothe) Hey hey - no no - you're all right... But he is starting to PANIC. His eyes fix fearfully to th floor as his breathing grows erratic. Then:

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey: hey: Charlie. Peter's breathing HALTS. He looks up to Joan, still trembling. Eyes wide.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're all right now. A long silence as Peter searches Joan's face for understanding. Peter finally SPEAKS...but he sounds more CHARLIE than Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Who am I? A loaded pause from Joan. Then:

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You are Paimon. One of the eight Kings of Hell. Beat. Peter doesn’t react. He just stares at her, uncomprehending.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We have looked to the northwest and called you in. We’ve corrected your first body and give you now this healthy male host. We reject the Trinity and pray devoutly to you, great Paimon: give us your knowledge of all secret things and all mysteries of the Earth; bring us honor, wealth and good familiars; and bind all men to our Will, as we have bound ourselves for now and ever to Yours. We hear Joan return to her bowing position:

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hail Paimon. Peter’s eyes are buzzing. Then, from behind Joan:  156 118.

dialogues.speaker: WORSHIPPERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hail Paimon! Then, louder:

dialogues.speaker: JOAN/WORSHIPPERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hail Paimon!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE of the treehouse.

dialogues.speaker: WORSHIPPERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hail!! CUT HARD TO BLACK. HOLD ON THE BLACK. From this, we VERY SLOWLY FADE IN ON: A NEUTRAL WIDE OF THE GRAHAM HOUSE. NIGHT. Surrounded by dreamy snowfall. A strong artifice distinguishes the imag As if the actual house has somehow been replaced by its MINIATURE REPLICA. Even the drifting snowflakes look fals Hold on this as the CREDITS roll.
